metadata.title: The liquid-phase hydrogenation of TMCB for preparation of CBDO by fluorine-modified Ruthenium-Stannum bimetallic catalysts

The liquid-phase hydrogenation of TMCB for preparation of CBDO by fluorine-modified Ruthenium-Stannum bimetallic catalysts Hao Zhen Writing – original draft Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Conceptualization a Lei Ma Writing – review & editing Supervision Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Conceptualization a Teng Wang Writing – review & editing Visualization Validation Supervision Project administration a Yanqing Liu Writing – review & editing Visualization Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition b Changkun Liu Funding acquisition Project administration Supervision Visualization Writing – review & editing b Xianshan Wang Funding acquisition Project administration Supervision Visualization Writing – review & editing b Suohe Yang Validation Project administration Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation a Guangxiang He Visualization Validation Resources Project administration Conceptualization a Haibo Jin Writing – review & editing Visualization Resources Project administration Methodology Conceptualization a ⁎ a College of New Material and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Petrochemical Technology/Beijing Key Laboratory of Fuels Cleaning and Advanced Catalytic Emission Reduction Technology, Beijing 102617, China College of New Material and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Petrochemical Technology/Beijing Key Laboratory of Fuels Cleaning and Advanced Catalytic Emission Reduction Technology Beijing 102617 China College of New Material and Chemical Engineering, Beijing Institute of Petrochemical Technology/Beijing Key Laboratory of Fuels Cleaning and Advanced Catalytic Emission Reduction Technology, Beijing 102617, China b Zhenghe Group Co., Ltd., Dongying, Shandong 257342, China Zhenghe Group Co., Ltd. Dongying Shandong 257342 China Zhenghe Group Co., Ltd, Dongying 257342, Shandong, China ⁎ Corresponding author. A series of Ruthenium-Stannum bimetallic catalysts were prepared using the isovolumetric impregnation method and investigated for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of 2,2,4,4-tetramethyl-1,3-cyclobutanedione to its corresponding 2,2,4,4-tetramethyl-1,3-cyclobutanediol. The effects of the reaction temperature and pressure, fluorine-modified alumina, reaction solvent, and catalyst particle size on the catalytic performance were discussed. The optimum reaction conditions were obtained with a temperature of 80 ℃, a hydrogen pressure of 4.0 MPa, and a reaction solvent of tetrahydrofuran. In addition, characterization techniques, such as BET, XRD, TEM, NH3-TPD, and Py-IR, showed that the active component nanoparticles were effectively introduced into the alumina carriers, and the alumina was modified by a low concentration of NH4F solution (0.05 mol/L), which ensured that the complete conversion of 2,2,4,4-tetramethyl-1,3-cyclobutanedione was obtained while maintaining a selectivity of over 95 % for the 2,2,4,4-tetramethyl-1,3-cyclobutanediol. Graphical Abstract Keywords 2,2,4,4-tetramethyl-1,3-cyclobutanediol Ruthenium-Stannum bimetal Catalytic hydrogenation Ammonium fluoride modified Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Due to the pursuit of environmental protection and healthy living, the market demand for plastic products (especially high-performance or high-end resin products) is increasing. In 2007, Eastman Chemical Company (USA) developed a new generation of co-polyester, Tritan™, which can be used as an alternative to traditional polycarbonate (PC) in areas such as medical devices, appliance manufacturing, and food packaging [1]. Compared with PC, Tritan™ does not involve toxic bisphenol A (BPA) in production and use and has excellent impact strength and hydrolysis resistance, a higher glass transition temperature and transparency [2,3], easy molding, and low residual stress in the product. 2,2,4,4-tetramethyl-1,3-cyclobutanediol (CBDO) has high research value as one of the monomers in the production of copolyester Tritan™, and the main pathway for the synthesis of CBDO is the reduction reaction of 2,2,4,4-tetramethyl-1,3-cyclobutanedione (TMCB) with hydrogen in the presence of a catalyst, which turns the carbonyl groups on both sides of TMCB into hydroxyl groups. Therefore, the key technology for the preparation of CBDO is the development of efficient hydrogenation catalysts [4,5]. Among the many hydrogenation catalysts, those with Ruthenium as the active component show amazing potential for application. The quantum size effect and surface effect of metal nanoparticles enable Ruthenium nanoparticles to exhibit highly efficient activity and selectivity, which fundamentally distinguishes them from bulk metals [6,7]. In addition, metallic Ruthenium, as one of the most efficient and economical noble metals (its price is much lower than that of the noble metals Palladium or Platinum), is used in many aldehyde- or carbonyl-hydrogenation reactions, such as the hydrogenation of furfural to furfuryl alcohol [8], the hydrogenation of glucose to sorbitol [9,10], the hydrogenation of ethyl acetoacetate to β-hydroxybutyric acid ethyl ester [11], the hydrogenation of butanone to 2-butanol [12], and the hydrogenation of acetophenone to phenylethanol [13,14], etc. Similarly, studies on the hydrogenation of TMCB to CBDO have been reported; for example, Huang et al. [15] prepared Ru-based catalysts using nitric acid-modified activated carbon as a carrier and found that they exhibited excellent catalytic performance for TMCB hydrogenation; Si et al. [16] synthesized a series of Ru/AC catalysts with different particle sizes and found that the size of Ruthenium particles had a direct cis-trans ratio of the product CBDO influence. Ru-based catalysts have also been found to have high hydrogenation activity for carbon-carbon double bonds, such as the hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to succinic anhydride [7,17] and the hydrogenation of methyl methacrylate to methyl isobutyrate [18]. In summary, the Ru-based catalytic system is considered to be a promising system for hydrogenation. In the early stages of this group's research, it was found that the TMCB hydrogenation of monometallic Ru/Al2O3 catalysts was all less than optimal [19], and the selectivity of CBDO at the optimal temperature of 120 ℃ was only 70.4 %. Therefore, in order to improve the CBDO selectivity, adding a co-metal to the catalyst becomes a good choice. Related studies have also confirmed [20,21] that the addition of the co-metal Sn can improve the affinity of the catalyst surface for the carbonyl group compared with that of the monometallic Ru/Al2O3 catalyst, which is more favorable for the hydrogenation of the carbonyl group. Because the oxidation state of Sn can play the role of the Lewis acid center to activate the carbonyl group, which increases the polarizability of CO, it is easier for H activated by Ru to approach the CO bond, and thus the hydrogenation rate can be significantly increased [22–24]. Based on the above findings, this paper then prepared a series of Ru-Sn bimetallic catalysts based on Ru as the active component and Sn as the co-metal and investigated the effects of different reaction conditions, fluorine-modified alumina, reaction solvents, and catalyst particle sizes on the catalytic performances of the TMCB hydrogenation reaction. Analytical techniques such as BET, XRD, TEM, NH3-TPD, and Py-IR were employed to thoroughly investigate the intrinsic structure and performance relationships of the catalysts. The results showed that the yield of CBDO could reach more than 90 % at 80 ℃ when catalyzed by two metals, Ru and Sn, and with a certain acid strength on the surface of the catalyst, which compares with the results of the existing studies (Ru-based monometallic catalysts with activated carbon as the carrier) [5,16], and the optimal reaction temperature of the present experiments is reduced to 80 ℃ from the previous 130 ℃, which leads to a great reduction of the energy loss. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Activated alumina and sodium borohydride were obtained from Sinopharm. 2,2,4,4-tetramethyl-1,3-cyclobutanedione (99.0 %) and ammonium fluoride (99.99 %) were obtained from Shanghai Meryer Biochemical Technology Co. Hydrochloric acid (36 % ∼ 38 %) and n-octane (97.0 %) were obtained from Fuchen (Tianjin) Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Stannous chloride dihydrate (98.0 %) and tetrahydrofuran (99.0 %) were obtained from Beijing MREDA Technology Co. Ruthenium trichloride trihydrate (98.0 %) was obtained from Energy Chemical. Isobutanol was obtained from the Beijing Chemical Plant. Butyl acetate (99.0 %) was obtained from the Chengdu Chemical Reagent Plant. Isobutyl isobutyrate (98.0 %) was obtained from Shanghai Boer Chemical Reagent Co. High-purity hydrogen (99.999 %) was obtained from Beijing Huanyu Jinghui Jingcheng Gas Technology Co. All the water used in the experiments was deionized water. 2.2 Catalysts preparation A portion of the Al2O3 carrier was first treated with different concentrations of NH4F solution; the liquid-solid mass ratio was 10:1, and it was treated at a constant temperature of 80 ℃ for 24 h. The treated carrier was then filtered, washed, and finally dried. The Ruthenium catalysts were prepared by the equal volume impregnation method, in which SnCl2·2H2O was dissolved in a small amount of distilled water containing dilute hydrochloric acid, and then Al2O3 was added proportionally and stirred uniformly. The catalysts were dried at 80 ℃ for 2 h after 12 h of impregnation and then burned in a muffle furnace at 560 ℃ for 2 h. The Ru-based catalysts were then added to the specified concentration of RuCl3·3H2O and impregnated for a long period of time. After 12 h, the catalyst was dried in an oven at 80 ℃ for 2 h, and then a certain concentration of alkaline NaBH4 aqueous solution was added dropwise [n(NaBH4):n(Ru) = 4:1], and then washed by filtration until the filtrate was free of chlorine ions, and the residual chlorine ions in the catalyst would decrease the dispersion of Ru and thus reduce the activity of the catalyst [10], and the catalyst was finally dried to obtain the catalyst Ru-Sn/Al2O3. The specimens treated with 0.05, 0.2, and 0.5 mol/L NH4F solution were recorded as Ru-Sn/Al2O3-1, Ru-Sn/Al2O3-2, and Ru-Sn/Al2O3-3, respectively, and the specimens not treated with NH4F solution were recorded as Ru-Sn/Al2O3-0. 2.3 Catalysts characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out using a Rigaku Powerful Rotating Target Fully Automated X-ray Diffractometer (9kW_D/max-2600) with a measuring angle of 5–85° and a step scanning mode with a scanning step size as low as 0.01°. A BELSORP-mini II instrument was used to monitor the adsorption-desorption behavior of nitrogen, and Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET)-specific surface area was obtained, and the total pore volume and pore size were calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken on a JEM 2100 microscope operated at 200 kV. The NH3-TPD of the catalysts was performed using a Microtrac BEL BELCAT II instrument. The catalyst was first dried and pretreated at 300 ℃ for 1 h and then saturated with a 10 % NH3/He mixture. Finally, the catalyst was desorbed after warming to 700 ℃ in a helium atmosphere at a ramp rate of 20 ℃/min. Pyridine infrared adsorption spectroscopy (Py-FTIR) was performed using a Bruker tensor 27 Fourier infrared spectrometer. The milled samples were placed in a pressing mold to press self-supporting slices and then mounted in a vacuum in-situ cell at 400 ℃ for evacuation treatment. The pretreated samples were adsorbed with pyridine at room temperature and then desorbed at 200 ℃ and 350 ℃, respectively, with a scanning range between 1400–1700 cm−1 wave number. 2.4 Catalysts evaluation A 100-mL Parr autoclave was used to evaluate the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. Firstly, a tetrahydrofuran solution containing 3 % TMCB was placed in the kettle, and a quantitative amount of homemade catalyst was added. After connecting the device and checking the air tightness, hydrogen was introduced to replace the air in the kettle for 2–3 times, and then hydrogen was introduced to reach a pressure of 3.0 MPa, and then the heating and stirring system was turned on at a speed of 210 rpm. After the temperature was stabilized at 80 ℃, the reaction was continued with the slow introduction of hydrogen to reach a pressure of 4.0 MPa for 1 h. The catalyst was removed by centrifugation at the end of the reaction and cooled down to room temperature, and the supernatant was used for gas chromatography analysis. In order to ensure the accuracy of the results, several experiments were carried out under the same conditions, and the data were averaged within ±3 % variation. The reaction process of TMCB hydrogenation to CBDO was as follows: 2.5 Product analysis The liquid samples of the experimental products were analyzed by gas chromatography using a Shimadzu GC-2014 C with a TM-5 capillary column and detected by a flame ionization detector (FID). The TMCB conversion, CBDO selectivity, and yield given in this experiment are based on gas chromatographic calculations using n-octane as an internal standard reference compound. Where TMCB conversion is defined as the ratio of the number of moles of TMCB consumed in the reaction to the number of moles of TMCB in the feedstock; CBDO selectivity is defined as the ratio of the number of moles of CBDO produced by the reaction to the total number of moles of TMCB consumed; and CBDO yield is the product of conversion and selectivity. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization The pore structure parameters of the carriers and catalysts are summarized in Table 1. The specific surface area and pore volume of the catalysts decreased after the introduction of the active components Ru and SnO2, indicating that the active component nanoparticles were partially occupied in the mesopores of the carriers. The specific surface area and pore volume of the Ru-Sn/Al2O3 catalysts were further decreased with the increase in the concentration of the NH4F-treated solution, while the average pore diameter was gradually increased, which may be related to the fact that the high concentration of the fluorine treatment solution can significantly reduce the number of hydroxyl groups on the surface of alumina carriers [25]. As can be seen from Fig. 1, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalyst and the carrier alumina have similar shapes, both of which are typical IV-type isotherms, indicating that the prepared catalysts are characterized by mesoporous structure. The H3-type hysteresis loop due to capillary condensation appeared in both the medium and high pressure regions (0.5<P/P0<0.9), which can be presumed to be an inhomogeneous slit-like pore structure [26]. In summary, it can be seen that the catalyst has a higher surface area and pore volume, with a larger adsorption capacity and more adsorption sites, which is conducive to providing more sites for substrate adsorption in the TMCB hydrogenation reaction, which is in agreement with the TEM characterization results. As can be seen in Fig. 2, characteristic diffraction peaks of γ-Al2O3 (PDF#No.79–1558) appeared at 2θ of 37.4°, 45.8°, 60.54°, and 66.96° for both catalysts [27]. Weak characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ of 31.45°, 36.4°, 52.45°, and 62.58° were attributed to the diffraction peaks of SnO2 (PDF#No.33–1374), suggesting that Sn exists in the form of oxide SnO2 in both catalysts [28]. However, the characteristic diffraction signals of Ru were not detected for all samples, indicating that the prepared Ru nanoparticles were highly dispersed on the carriers [29], and their average diameters were below the detection limit of XRD. To summarize the results, it can be shown that the catalyst treated with a 0.05 mol/L NH4F solution did not change the original crystal structure. The TEM images of the catalysts and the corresponding particle size distributions are shown in Fig. 3. The black part is the active components of the catalysts (Ru and SnO2 nanoparticles), and the light gray part is the γ-Al2O3 carrier. It can be seen that the active components of the two catalysts have clear shapes and uniform sizes, and they are all dispersed more uniformly on the carriers, where a small amount of agglomeration occurs in the fluorine-modified catalysts, which is probably related to the better acid strength of the carriers. The average size of the active component particles was determined by using nanomeasurer software, and the results showed that the active metal particles of catalysts Ru-Sn/Al2O3-0 and Ru-Sn/Al2O3-1 showed a narrow size distribution, with a small difference in the average sizes of 1.26 nm and 1.42 nm, respectively. According to the NH3-TPD characterization results ( Fig. 4), desorption peaks existed near 120 ℃, 300 ℃, and 400 ℃ for both catalysts, which were weak, medium-strong, and strong acid centers, respectively. For the Ru-Sn/Al2O3-1 catalyst, it was found that the area of the high-temperature desorption peaks increased significantly near 400 ℃ after the alumina was treated with ammonium fluoride, i.e., it corresponded to the increase of the strong acid center. This is because the principle of ammonium fluoride modification is that fluorine replaces the hydroxyl group on the surface of alumina [30], and elemental fluorine has strong electronegativity, which attracts the electrons of the hydroxyl group around the aluminum atom, making it easier for the hydrogen protons on the hydroxyl group to ionize and form the Brönsted acidic site, which enhances the acidity of alumina [31]. Therefore, the high-temperature desorption peak appearing at 400 ℃ in Fig. 4 indicates the process of fluorine substitution of hydroxyl groups, which also confirms that the moderate fluorine treatment of alumina in this experiment enhances the amount of acid in the strong acid center of the catalyst. As shown in Table 2, both Lewis and Brönsted acid sites are present on the surface of both catalysts [32]. The surface of the unfluoridated Ru-Sn/Al2O3-0 catalyst is mainly dominated by Lewis acid centers, and the total amount of both L and B acids increases after the alumina is treated with appropriate fluorine. In addition, for both L and B acids of the same catalyst, both the acid area and the acid amount decreased with the increase of the desorption temperature, and when the desorption temperature was 200 ℃, the total acid amount of the fluorine-treated catalyst increased from 37.63 to 45.74 μmol/g, indicating that NH4F modification of alumina significantly increased the surface acidity of the catalysts, and the trend was consistent with the NH3-TPD characterization results. Based on the Py-IR characterization results ( Fig. 5), it was further shown that in both catalysts, the amount of acid in the L acid center was much larger than that of the B acid, where the corresponding absorption spectral peaks of the L acid center were 1445, 1491, and 1594 cm−1, respectively, while the characteristic absorption peaks of the B acid center were insignificant, but the absorption peaks of the B acid site at 1541 and 1637 cm−1 were significantly enhanced after the treatment with ammonium fluoride [33,34]. This is also due to the high electronegativity of elemental fluorine, and the intensity of the residual L acid sites is enhanced by the induced effect of fluorine [35]. 3.2 Activity testing of TMCB hydrogenation catalysts The catalytic activity of the Ruthenium-Stannum catalysts was first investigated under different reaction conditions ( Table 3). The conversion of TMCB could reach 99.90 % when the reaction temperature was 70 ℃, at which time the selectivity of CBDO was 84.74 %. As the temperature was increased to 80 ℃ and 90 ℃, the conversion of TMCB was also increased to about 99.98 %, whereas the selectivity of CBDO reached a maximum value of 93.03 % at 80 ℃. Continuing to examine the reaction pressure at the reaction temperature of 80 ℃, it was found that the selectivity of CBDO gradually increased with the increase in hydrogen pressure, while the results at hydrogen pressure up to 5 MPa were not much different from those at 4 MPa. In conclusion, 80 ℃ and 4 MPa may be the optimal reaction conditions for this experiment, and the efficient conversion of TMCB to CBDO at a low temperature (80 ℃) may be attributed to the fact that the active metal Ru itself has a polarizing effect on the carbonyl group and also activates the hydrogen molecules to undergo heterolytic cleavage [36]. The presence of Sn further enhances the catalyst's affinity for the carbonyl group, which in turn raises the degree of polarization of CO and makes it easier to bring H closer to the CO bond after activation by Ru [21]. Moreover, the cis-trans ratio of CBDO hardly changed with the changes in temperature and pressure, and its ratio basically remained around 1.20. The catalytic properties of the NH4F-modified Ru-based catalysts are shown in Table 4. It can be seen that the original carrier, Al2O3, has no reactivity for TMCB hydrogenation. Under the same reaction conditions, the four catalysts had excellent catalytic performance for TMCB, and basically all of them could realize the complete conversion of TMCB; however, for the selectivity of CBDO, it was found that the catalyst (Ru-Sn/Al2O3-1) treated with a 0.05 mol/L NH4F solution had the best effect (95.88 %) on enhancing the selectivity of CBDO, which was significantly higher than that of the unmodified catalyst and the catalyst treated with a high concentration of NH4F solution. This may be due to the fact that moderate fluorine modification increases the content of strong acids in the catalyst, resulting in more active sites and thus more favorable for catalytic hydrogenation reactions, but excessive fluorine treatment destroys the structure and acid sites of alumina [30], which ultimately decreases the selectivity of the reaction product CBDO. Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (5977 GCMS) analysis showed that the ring-opening byproducts were mainly 1-(1-butenyloxy)-pentane and 1-(vinyloxy)-3-methylbutane, among others. Because fluorine-modified catalysts enhance surface acidity, they have high catalytic activity for acid-catalyzed reactions such as cleavage and isomerization [33]. In addition, it has been reported [37] that cycloalkane compounds may undergo deep hydrogenation and selective ring-opening reactions over certain noble metal catalysts (e.g., Pt, Ir, Ru, etc.). Therefore, due to the combined effect between acid sites and noble metal sites in the catalysts [38,39], for the catalytic hydrogenation reaction of TMCB, TMCB may be prone to generating a higher amount of ring-opening byproducts if they are not under optimal reaction conditions. The catalytic activities of different reaction solvents were investigated, and the experimental results are shown in Table 5. From the conversion of TMCB in different solvents, tetrahydrofuran and isobutyl alcohol could achieve more than 99.90 % conversion, while butyl acetate and isobutyl isobutyrate as solvents still left more feedstock TMCB after the completion of the reaction. From the perspective of the selectivity of CBDO in different solvents, the selectivity of tetrahydrofuran as a solvent reaches more than 90 %, and there are fewer ring-opening byproducts. Although the cis-trans ratio of CBDO (1.19) is low, its yield is much higher than that of the other three solvents, which may be attributed to the greater polarity of the solvent tetrahydrofuran. The catalytic activities of different catalyst carriers were investigated, and the experimental results are shown in Table 6. Under the same catalyst preparation and reaction conditions, the reaction of TMCB-catalyzed hydrogenation was poor when activated carbon was used as the carrier for the active component, and the TMCB conversion, CBDO selectivity, and CBDO cis-trans ratio were much lower than those of alumina. Therefore, alumina was the most suitable carrier in this experiment. For activated carbon, the CBDO cis-trans ratio was only 1.04. Combined with the experimental results of Huang [15] and Si [16], it was indicated that the content of cis-isomers in the product CBDO was generally lower with activated carbon as the carrier, while alumina was effective in improving the selectivity of cis-isomers, which might be related to the fact that alumina carriers have a certain amount of acid by themselves. Finally, the catalytic activities of catalysts with different mesh sizes were investigated ( Table 7). Under the same reaction conditions, the catalysts with 60 mesh and above were higher than those with 40–60 mesh in terms of both conversion and selectivity, indicating that the smaller size of the catalyst particles was more effective for the reaction of TMCB catalytic hydrogenation. This is because the smaller the size, the larger the specific surface area, the more active component Ru is exposed on the surface of the catalyst, which indirectly increases the contact probability of Ru with TMCB and H2 in the solvent, and thus the catalytic hydrogenation reaction can be carried out more adequately. However, since it is more difficult to separate the product and catalyst when the catalyst is smaller, 40–60 mesh catalysts, which are easy to separate solids from liquids, were used in this experiment. 4 Conclusions The present study has convincingly shown that the hydrogenation of TMCB to CBDO can be effectively carried out using a 40–60 mesh Ruthenium–Stannum bimetallic catalyst. Under the optimized reaction conditions, including a temperature of 80 ℃, a hydrogen pressure of 4 MPa, and tetrahydrofuran as the solvent, a remarkable 99.97 % conversion of TMCB was obtained within 1 h, and the selectivity of CBDO was also over 90 %. Furthermore, when the alumina carrier was modified with a moderate amount of ammonium fluoride, it led to an increase in the amount of surface acid in the catalyst. This enhancement in acidity not only enabled the complete conversion of TMCB but also increased the selectivity of CBDO to 95.88 %. In addition, the alumina carrier with trace acidity itself was also found to increase CBDO cis-isomer selectivity. In summary, this study successfully developed an efficient CBDO catalyst, which solved the previous problem of obtaining a high yield of CBDO only under high temperature conditions, but a series of challenges still exist in the future, such as how to simplify the whole process and realize the industrialization of CBDO preparation. coredata.dc:description: A series of Ruthenium-Stannum bimetallic catalysts were prepared using the isovolumetric impregnation method and investigated for the liquid-phase hydrogenation of 2,2,4,4-tetramethyl-1,3-cyclobutanedione to its corresponding 2,2,4,4-tetramethyl-1,3-cyclobutanediol. The effects of the reaction temperature and pressure, fluorine-modified alumina, reaction solvent, and catalyst particle size on the catalytic performance were discussed. The optimum reaction conditions were obtained with a temperature of 80 ℃, a hydrogen pressure of 4.0 MPa, and a reaction solvent of tetrahydrofuran. In addition, characterization techniques, such as BET, XRD, TEM, NH3-TPD, and Py-IR, showed that the active component nanoparticles were effectively introduced into the alumina carriers, and the alumina was modified by a low concentration of NH4F solution (0.05 mol/L), which ensured that the complete conversion of 2,2,4,4-tetramethyl-1,3-cyclobutanedione was obtained while maintaining a selectivity of over 95 % for the 2,2,4,4-tetramethyl-1,3-cyclobutanediol.

coredata.dc:title: The liquid-phase hydrogenation of TMCB for preparation of CBDO by fluorine-modified Ruthenium-Stannum bimetallic catalysts
